title: Add ODBC support
author: mihmig
body_snippet: Is it possible to add ODBC support to handle connection list (not only MSSQL)?

iterations.description: The request does not specify whether ODBC is for connection storage, import/export, or a new protocol, so scope and acceptance criteria are missing.
ODBC support is a clear, in-scope extension of the existing database-backed connection list feature that currently uses provider-specific connectors.
ODBC support for SQL-backed connection list storage is an in-scope extension of the existing MSSQL/MySQL database connector architecture.
ODBC-backed connection-list storage is a valid extension of the existing MSSQL/MySQL database connector architecture and can be added without changing remote protocol handling.

notes:
AI triage (codex): The request does not specify whether ODBC is for connection storage, import/export, or a new protocol, so scope and acceptance criteria are missing.
Approach: Ask for the exact ODBC use case (provider/DSN/auth/read-write expectations), then add an ODBC connector path, wire it into options UI, and cover it with integration tests.
AI triage (codex): ODBC support is a clear, in-scope extension of the existing database-backed connection list feature that currently uses provider-specific connectors.
Approach: Add an ODBC connector and wire it into provider selection, registry validation, and connection testing, then extend SQL connection integration coverage for the new provider path.
AI triage (codex): ODBC support for SQL-backed connection list storage is an in-scope extension of the existing MSSQL/MySQL database connector architecture.
Approach: Implement an ODBC connector type and selection path, update SQL options and registry validation plus connection testing to handle it, and add integration coverage for ODBC-backed connection load/save.
AI triage (gemini): ODBC-backed connection-list storage is a valid extension of the existing MSSQL/MySQL database connector architecture and can be added without changing remote protocol handling.
Approach: Add an ODBC connector type and selection flow in settings/UI, update connection testing and registry wiring for the provider, and add integration tests for ODBC-backed connection load/save.
